contentlets.description: This studio investigates the paradigms and typologies of urban design to develop a vocabulary of urban space upon which design studio projects can be designed. This is integrated with a conceptual project, which provides an initial opportunity to apply what has been learnt to a specific urban setting.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"UDES0002 - Urban Design Studio 2","description":"

This studio investigates a large scale and complex urban development (or redevelopment) area, usually in Sydney or another major urban centre in NSW. A broad analysis of the social, economic, environmental and regulatory factors shaping urban form is followed by the development of an urban design framework for future development. The emphasis is on creating socially responsible and commercially feasible urban environment with reference to current city making principles, in particular sustainable development, urban consolidation and transit oriented development.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0601e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Planning Context and Site Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Initial site investigation and analysis, focused on forming an understanding of the physical and planning conditions which pertain to the site and its surrounds within the urban area at a range of regional and local scales.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0601e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0601e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619f0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Stage 1 DA","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Students work individually to develop an urban design and planning framework for one mixed use block from the previously established precinct plan.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0601e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619ec","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Analysis, Opportunities and Design Principles","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students respond to the conditions identified in the previous assessment (site investigation and analysis) by formulating a set of opportunities coupled with a robust set of design principles. The opportunities and principles establish a measurable base which guides the subsequent assessment tasks. This assessment also provides an opportunity for critical reflection through iterative review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0601e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Precinct Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students work individually to apply the opportunities and design principles developed in Assessment Two to prepare a comprehensive precinct plan comprising of street hierarchy, walkable blocks, open space network and public transport.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0601e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ca01e098db7dfc90be4672f5f39619dc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/UDES0002.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This studio investigates a large scale and complex urban development (or redevelopment) area, usually in Sydney or another major urban centre in NSW. A broad analysis of the social, economic, environmental and regulatory factors shaping urban form is followed by the development of an urban design framework for future development. The emphasis is on creating socially responsible and commercially feasible urban environment with reference to current city making principles, in particular sustainable development, urban consolidation and transit oriented development.
contentlets.title: Urban Design Studio 2

The studio focuses on major urban projects in international cities. The location of the city will vary each year and involve 2 alternative locations. Central to the studio is developing an understanding of the urban context in socio-cultural, political, economic and environmental terms through expert briefings and field investigations, together with consideration of these factors in the urban design process and creative design outcomes. The studio normally involves two weeks of intensive overseas studio and field work (sometimes in collaboration with a local university or city agency) followed by 5 to 6 weeks of studio work back in Australia.

Critical urban projects from Australia and overseas are presented and analysed in order to assess the validity of their objectives and the effectiveness of their development processes, together with their design qualities and contribution to the public realm, the culture of the city and the welfare of its citizens. The object is to demonstrate through practical examples how major projects are conceived, financed, designed and built. The success or failure of projects now operational will be assessed on social, economic, environmental and aesthetic grounds.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"UDES0008 - Planning and Urban Development","description":"

This course provides a critical overview of property development in relation to planning controls. It examines the range of factors (economic, social, environmental, political, ideological) which operate within, or impinge upon, the 'planning system', and which in turn affect and regulate urban development possibilities. Understanding the relationship between processes of urban development and the regulation of this development through statutory planning systems is central to urban design. Hence, this course deals with the nature of planning systems, planning controls and property development processes, as well as the ways in which they interact at the scale of the urban project.

This course critically examines the role of landscape architecture and heritage conservation in shaping the modern city. It explores the inter-relationship of ecology, history, urban morphology, urban conservation, open space systems, public life and the culture of cities, showing how theoretical constructs, planning principles and design outcomes have changed with the changing landscapes of production and consumption in cities of the developed and developing world. The course includes background investigations of the cities selected for the international urban design studios in Summer Term.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"UDES0010 - Communication in Urban Design","description":"

As urban design is 'design for design' - setting up the objectives, principles and guidelines for complex urban projects to be designed in detail over time - effective communication is fundamental to the field. This course extends students' capacities for graphic, written and verbal communication through the production of the annual MUDD Folio, Exhibition and associated public lecture - the Paul Reid Lecture in Urban Design. The aim is to critically reflect upon and re-present the year's work of the MUDD Program in a creative, compelling format which contributes to the design culture of Sydney.

contentlets.description: As urban design is 'design for design' - setting up the objectives, principles and guidelines for complex urban projects to be designed in detail over time - effective communication is fundamental to the field. This course extends students' capacities for graphic, written and verbal communication through the production of the annual MUDD Folio, Exhibition and associated public lecture - the Paul Reid Lecture in Urban Design. The aim is to critically reflect upon and re-present the year's work of the MUDD Program in a creative, compelling format which contributes to the design culture of Sydney.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"UDES0011 - Urban Design Research Project","description":"

This course provides students enrolled in the Master of Urban Development and Design the opportunity to research a critical aspect of urban development and design, in either written dissertation or design thesis mode. Students will apply research and design method skills acquired in BENV7020 Research Methods in the development and delivery of an independent research project under the guidance of a BE supervisor.


Students will be encouraged to undertake research into an area that interests them. Students may wish to return to, and explore in more critical depth, a topic area introduced in previous MUDD courses. Alternatively, students may have research ideas and interests inspired by current advances in practice. The student's Research Proposal developed in BENV7020 will be discussed, refined and agreed between student and supervisor as the basis for the semester's work, subject to final approval from the MUDD Program Director.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961999","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 4 - Completed Research Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

The UDES0011 Urban Design Research Project in written format consists of three main parts: front matter; text; and end matter.
The front matter includes all material that precedes the main text of the work. This section is set off from the rest by lower-case roman page numbering, and serves to introduce the reader to the content and structure of the text. It includes the title page, the table of contents, the list of illustrations, acknowledgements and the abstract.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4861241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 2 - Draft Chapters","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Research Project production is an iterative process of research and writing, research and rewriting. A research plan is a vital means of structuring this work. This plan can take many forms, but in general, it should align research tasks with specific writing objectives. It is also helpful to consider where, when and how you will conduct your research and writing, and develop a detailed schedule of production, most powerfully with a set time for writing mandated each day. Such plans are an effective means of focusing research on production, and help achieve submission deadlines in a positive manner as you meet milestones you have set.

Students are to bring hard copies to the UDES0011 Research Seminar, be prepared to read sections aloud and discuss; in addition, discuss with your supervisor in detail over Weeks 2 & 9 (note that a pdf of the 80% Draft is also to be uploaded to the UDES0011 Moodle site)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1 - Refinement Research Topic","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Between the completion of BENV7020 Research Seminar and commencement of the writing phase of the Urban Design Research Project, topics are often refined as research progresses. This is acceptable and expected to the extent that it is productive and remains within the scheduled program for completion. Project 1 therefore explores the relevence and suitability of the research topic in refining it to suit the context of UDES0011.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c061241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619bb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 3 - Oral Presentation & Defence","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

10-minute Powerpoint presentation (followed by 10 minutes of questions, answers and discussion), as scheduled in the MUDD Studio.
Prepare a well-illustrated Powerpoint presentation of your Urban Design Research (10-20 slides) and a 1-page written summary (20 copies), plus a clear, compelling 10-minute oral presentation with strategic use of images and text on your slides (no hand held notes). Students are to practice their oral presentation, to stay within the 10-minute time limit. Be prepared to answer searching questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f751241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ff51241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cc61241cdb7dfc90be4672f5f39619af","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/UDES0011.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"UDES0012 - Elements of Urban Design","description":"

This course provides an introduction to the role of urban design in the making of the built environment. Grounded in a critical appreciation of design principles, topics include site investigation, defining urban structure, enhancing the public realm, understanding building typologies, and controlling built form. The course is structured around lectures, methodological instruction, discussions, case studies, site visits, and design projects. Assessments are based on individual and group projects. Students submit projects in written reports and oral presentations, supported by drawings, sketches and images. Elements of Urban Design is a foundational course offered at graduate level for students undertaking the Graduate Certificate in Built Environment. It provides students from a non-cognate discipline an introductory understanding of urban design theory and practice. Students will acquire a base level of knowledge and skills to enter the Master of Urban Development and Design.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"UDES0013 - Urban Design Graphics","description":"

This Studio-based course provides an introduction to the graphic communication skills necessary for the study and practice of urban design. Students will develop drawing skills from free-hand sketches to the production of plans, sections, elevations and three dimensional representations of the urban environment both by hand and computer. SketchUp, Adobe Photoshop and InDesign will allow students to learn how to render and enhance their technical drawings and final presentations.

contentlets.description: This Studio-based course provides an introduction to the graphic communication skills necessary for the study and practice of urban design. Students will develop drawing skills from free-hand sketches to the production of plans, sections, elevations and three dimensional representations of the urban environment both by hand and computer. SketchUp, Adobe Photoshop and InDesign will allow students to learn how to render and enhance their technical drawings and final presentations.
contentlets.title: Urban Design Graphics
